Award.AwardTitle: SusCHEM: Mixtures of Ionic Liquids with Compressible Fluids for Biopolymer Separations and Processing of Lignocellulosic Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1509390
Kiran
VA Polytechnic Inst

The proposed research program will explore a novel approach for separation of the biopolymers of lignocellulosic materials or woody biomass. The successful outcomes are expected to lead to purified cellulose and hemicellulose fractions that are free of extractives and lignin; or to purified lignin fractions that are free of carbohydrates. The possibility of generating uniform cellulose resources that are free of extractives and lignin is of high technological significance. Such a resource would greatly improve the efficiency and the sustainable production of biofuels such as bioethanol; or may be used as advanced fiber source for paper manufacture, or for production of cellulosic aerogels or scaffolds. The possibility of generating a uniform lignin resource is also of high significance. If it were available, such a resource could be used for possible conversion to nonpetroleum-based, hydrocarbon-like transportation fuels, or for conversion to advanced materials such a carbon fibers or porous adsorbents.

As solvent media, the project will explore mixtures of selected ionic liquids with a supercritical or compressible fluid such as carbon dioxide plus an organic solvent. The approach is non-traditional in that the focus will be on using the ionic liquids not as the major, but as a minor component of the mixtures. The objective is to incorporate the functionality or solvating power of the ionic liquids to mixtures of an organic solvent with a more compressible supercritical fluid at a level that would be just sufficient for separation and processing of biopolymers. The methodology is to combine the pressure-tunability of compressible fluids with the solvating power of ionic liquids while at the same time lowering the viscosity of the medium for easier processability. The goal is to develop solvent-antisolvent combinations that can be tuned for selective dissolution and precipitation of target polymers with manipulations of pressure and /or temperature, while at the same time facilitating the recovery and the recycle of the ionic liquids employed. Towards these objectives, the project will generate fundamental data on the high-pressure miscibility, volumetric properties, solubility parameters and viscosity of mixtures of selected ionic liquids with compressible fluids and their mixtures with the biopolymers of interest as a function of the fluid composition, pressure and temperature. The proposed combination of ionic liquids with compressible or supercritical fluid mixtures at high pressures are expected to provide new process flexibilities in terms of pressure, temperature, or compositional tuning of (a) the thermodynamic conditions for miscibility and phase separation, or (b) the transport properties such as viscosity, or (c) the kinetics with respect to either chemical reactivity and transformations, or (d) the thermophysical transitions and morphological modifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we explored a novel approach for processing of lignocellulosic materials towards development of alternative pathways that may facilitate generation of cellulose fractions that may be free of extractives and lignin, or generation of lignin fractions that may be free of carbohydrates. Cellulose fractions that are free of lignin can be an attractive resource for production of biofuels such as ethanol, or as a resource for the manufacture of not only traditional products like paper, but for advanced materials like cellulose-based aerogels. The possibility of producing a carbohydrate-free lignin would be of high interest as a new resource for conversion of biomass materials to advanced materials like carbon fibers or porous adsorbents.

Our general concept has been to work with compressed mixtures of ionic liquids with organic solvents.  The primary interest was on imidazolium-based ionic liquids and their mixtures with ethanol.  The approach was non-traditional in that the focus was on using the ionic liquids not as the major, but as the minor additive component of the mixture.  The goal was to incorporate the solvating power of ionic liquids with the pressure tunability of compressible fluids, while at the same time reducing the viscosity of the medium for easier processing and post-recovery.

Towards these goals, the project aimed at first generating fundamental data on the high-pressure miscibility, volumetric properties, solubility parameters and viscosity of selected ionic liquid-solvent mixtures.  Until the present investigation, information on the effect of pressure on the solubility parameter of solvent mixtures was rare and was totally lacking for mixtures involving ionic liquids in the literature. We have published the results in the Journal of Supercritical Fluids (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.supflu.2014.12.017) and in Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research ( https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.iecr.9b02574).

An equally important consideration was the assessment of the thermal stability and the kinetics of decomposition of the ionic liquids of interest. Often, ionic liquids are referred to as being solvents with no vapor pressure, but this does not mean that they are thermally stable. Even though for short exposure times they may appear stable, long term exposure may cause severe degradation of the ionic liquid at high temperatures. In solutions, the stability depends on the nature of the solvent.  Until the present investigation, some of the key long-term thermal stability issues of ionic liquids had not been fully explored, and there was no prior study on the thermal stability of their solutions under high pressure conditions. Our findings have been published in two articles that appeared in Thermochimica Acta (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tca.2018.09.013; and  https://org/10.1016/j.tca.2020.178905) and have been recently presented at the 18th European meeting on Supercritical Fluids (EMSF 2021), Bordeaux, France, May 2021.

Extraction evaluations were carried out using bamboo as a renewable biomass sample with solutions of two selected ionic liquids, 1-ethyl-3-methyl imidazolium acetate ([EMIM]Ac),  or  1-butyl-3-methyl imidazolium chloride ([BMIM]Cl), in ethanol. A novel high-pressure extraction system consisting of a high-pressure view-cell equipped with two sapphire windows for direct observations of the cell interior housing a magnetically-rotated peforated sample basket was employed.  The perforated basket allows efficient contact with the extraction fluid, but prevents contamination of the extract solution with fragments of the unextracted portion of the material being processed.  This arrangment allows for the easy recovery of both the extraced material, and extract solutions.  Sapphire windows  permit for the visual or optical observations of the extract solution  during the experiments.  

The results show that even at 1 wt % addition level, incorporation of either [EMIM]Ac or [BMIM]Cl improves the extraction level over that is achievable with ethanol alone. Extractions were highest with [EMIM]Ac solutions. The extracted chips were analyzed with (1) Scanning Electron Microscopy for the changes in the cell-wall integrity; (2) Thermogravimetric Analysis to assess the changes in the cellulose-to-lignin ratio; and (3) Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy to assess the changes in the ratio of crystalline-to-amorphous cellulose (Crystallinity Index) and the changes in the ratio of the amorphous cellulose-to-lignin (Treatment Index).  

The comparative evaluations of the cellulose-to-lignin ratio show that while [EMIM]Ac solutions dissolve more lignin, solutions of [BMIM]Cl dissolve more of the cellulosic fractions.  The changes in the Crystallinity Index show that solutions of [EMIM]Ac dissolve more of the amorphous cellulose fractions. Treatment Index values also show that the amorphous cellulose fraction in the extracted bamboo is lower after extractions with solutions of [EMIM]Ac compared to the extractions with solutions of [BMIM]Cl. These findings were recently presented at the 18th European Meeting on Supercritical Fluids (EMSF 2021) held in Bordeaux, France in May 2021.

Further details of volumetric properties, stability, extractions, and the effectiveness of the various ionic liquid + ethanol mixtures are available in the Ph.D. Thesis of Michael L. Williams, Pressurized Mixtures of Ionic Liquids as Process Solvents for Biomass, Ph.D. Thesis, Virginia Tech, 2020.
